Feeling too tired or not having enough time are common excuses for avoiding exercise, and it can be challenging to overcome this mental block. Here are some tips that may help:

1. Start small: Instead of trying to do a full workout right away, start with small, achievable goals, such as walking for 10 minutes or doing a few stretches. Once you start seeing progress, you may feel more motivated to do more.

2. Schedule exercise time: Treat exercise like an appointment and schedule it into your day. Make it a non-negotiable part of your routine, just like eating or sleeping.

3. Find opportunities throughout the day: You don't have to set aside a specific time for exercise; there are plenty of opportunities throughout the day to move more. Take the stairs instead of the elevator, go for a walk during your lunch break, or do some stretches while watching TV.

4. Make it social:    Exercise with a friend or join a class. It can not only make your workouts more enjoyable but also keep you accountable and motivated.

5. Use positive self-talk: When negative thoughts creep in, replace them with positive affirmations. Focus on the benefits of exercise and how it makes you feel, instead of the barriers.

6. Remind yourself why it's important: Think about the reasons why exercise is important to you, such as improving your health or stress relief. Remind yourself of the benefits and use them as motivation to keep going.

Remember to be patient and kind with yourself. It takes time to create new habits, but with consistent effort and a positive mindset, you can overcome mental blocks and make exercise a regular part of your routine.
